Question:
The value of
3 ÷ 18 of 3 × 6 + 21 × 6 ÷ 18 - 3 ÷ 2 + 3 - 3 ÷ 9 of 3 × 9 is:
Solution:
Follow the BODMAS as given below in the table:

The given expression is:
3 ÷ 18 of 3 × 6 + 21 × 6 ÷ 18 - 3 ÷ 2 + 3 - 3 ÷ 9 of 3 × 9
⇒ 3 ÷ 54 × 6 + 21 × 6 × 1/18 - 3 × 1/2 + 3 - 3 ÷ 27 × 9
⇒ 3 × 1/54 × 6 + 7 - 3/2 + 3 - 3 × 1/27 × 9
⇒ 1/3 + 7 - 3/2 +3 - 1
⇒ (2 + 42 - 9 + 18 - 6)/6
⇒ (62 - 15)/6
⇒ 47/6

Question: In ΔABC, D and E are the midpoints of sides BC and AC, respectively, If AD = 10.8 cm, BE = 14.4 cm and AD and BE intersect at G at a right angle, then the area (in cm<sup>2</sup>) of ΔABC is:
Solution:
Given:
In ΔABC, D and E are the midpoints of sides BC and AC, respectively
AD = 10.8 cm
BE = 14.4 cm
AD and BE intersect at G at a right angle
Concept used:
Centroid always divide the median in 2 ∶ 1
Centroid always divide the area of the triangle into 6 equal parts
Calculations:

D and E is the midpoint of BC so AD and BE is median respectively
Centroid always divide the median in 2 ∶ 1
AG = (2/3) × AD
⇒ AG = (2/3) × 10.8
⇒ AG = 7.2 cm
Similarly, BG = (2/3) × BE
⇒ BG = (2/3) × 14.4
⇒ BG = 9.6 cm
In ΔAGB,
∠AGB = 90°
So, area of ΔAGB = (1/2) × AG × BG
⇒ (1/2) × 9.6 × 7.2
⇒ 34.56 cm2

Area of ΔAGB = Area of ΔAGF + Area of ΔBGF
⇒ Area of ΔAGB = (1/6) × Area of ΔABC + (1/6) × Area of ΔABC
⇒ Area of ΔAGB = (1/3) × Area of ΔABC
⇒ Area of ΔABC = 3 × Area of ΔAGB
⇒ Area of ΔABC = 3 × 34.56
⇒ Area of ΔABC = 103.68 cm2
∴ Area of ΔABC is 103.68 cm2

Question: Rishu saves x% of her income. If her income increases by 26% and the expenditure increases by 20%, then her savings increase by 50%. What is the value of x?
Solution:
Given:
Rishu saves x% of her income
Increase in her income = 26%
Increase in her expenditure = 20%
Increase in saving = 50%
Concept used:
Income = Saving + Expenditure
Calculations:
Let income of Rishu be 100
Saving of Rishu = 100 × (x/100) = x
Expenditure of Rishu = 100 – x
Rishu's salary after increment = 100 × (126/100) = 126
Rishu's expenditure after increment = (100 – x) × 120/100 = (100 – x) × 6/5
New Saving = 126 – (100 – x) × 6/5 ----(1)
New saving after increment = x × 150/100
New saving after increment = 3x/2 ----(2)
From eq. (1) and eq. (2)
⇒ 126 – (100 – x) × 6/5 = 3x/2
⇒ 126 – 120 + 6x/5 = 3x/2
⇒ 6 = (3x/2) – (6x/5)
⇒ 6 = (15x – 12x)/10
⇒ x = 20
∴ The value of x is 20.
Additional Information
ExpenditureIncomeSavings
20%26%50%
(50 - 26)% = 24%(26 - 20)% = 6%
So, 24 : 6 ⇒ 4 : 1 ∴ Savings (x%) = \(1\over5\) × 100 = 20%

Question: If \(\frac{{45}}{{53}} = \frac{1}{{a + \frac{1}{{b + \frac{1}{{c - \frac{2}{5}}}}}}},\) where a, b and c are positive integers, then what is the value of (4a - b + 3c)

A person divides a certain amount among his three sons in the ratio of 3 ∶ 4 ∶ 5. If he had divided this amount in the ratio of 1/3,1/4,1/5, his son, who had got the lowest share earlier, would get Rs.1,188 more. Find the amount (in Rs).
Solution:
Given:
A person divides a certain amount among his three sons in the ratio = 3 ∶ 4 ∶ 5
If he had divided this amount in the ratio = 1/3 ∶ 1/4 ∶ 1/5
The person who had got the lowest share earlier would get Rs. 1,188 more
Calculations:
A person divides a certain amount among his three sons in the ratio = 3 ∶ 4 ∶ 5
Let money get by first, second and third son be 3x, 4x and 5x respectively
Total share = 3x + 4x + 5x = 12x
Here first son got minimum share i.e 3x
If person had divided total amount in the ratio = 1/3 ∶ 1/4 ∶ 1/5
LCM of 3, 4 and 5 = 60
Ratio of First, second and third = (1/3) × 60 ∶ (1/4) × 60 ∶ (1/5) × 60
⇒ 20 ∶ 15 ∶ 12
Share of first son = (20/47) × Total share
Share of first son = (20/47) × 12x
⇒ 240x/47
According to the question
⇒ (240x/47) – (3x) = 1188
⇒ (240x – 141x)/47 = 1188
⇒ 99x/47 = 1188
⇒ x = 12 × 47
⇒ x = 564
Total amount = 12x
⇒ 12 × 564 = Rs. 6768
∴ The total amount is Rs. 6768

Question: The value of \(\frac{{{{\sec }^2}\theta \left( {2 + {{\tan }^2}\theta + {{\cot }^2}\theta } \right) \div \left( {{{\sin }^2}\theta - {{\tan }^2}\theta } \right)\;}}{{\left( {cose{c^2}\theta + {{\sec }^2}\theta } \right){{\left( {1 + {{\cot }^2}\theta } \right)}^2}}}\) is:
Solution:
Given:
\(\frac{{{\rm{se}}{{\rm{c}}^2}{\rm{θ }}\left( {2{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;ta}}{{\rm{n}}^2}{\rm{θ \;}} + {\rm{\;co}}{{\rm{t}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right) \div \left( {{\rm{si}}{{\rm{n}}^2}{\rm{θ \;}} - {\rm{\;ta}}{{\rm{n}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right)}}{{\left( {{\rm{cose}}{{\rm{c}}^2}{\rm{θ \;}} + {\rm{\;se}}{{\rm{c}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right){{\left( {1{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;co}}{{\rm{t}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right)}^2}}}\)
Concept used:
As only one angle is given, so we put any angle in expression and get the answer.
Calculation:
Let, θ = 45°
\(\frac{{{\rm{se}}{{\rm{c}}^2}{\rm{θ }}\left( {2{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;ta}}{{\rm{n}}^2}{\rm{θ \;}} + {\rm{\;co}}{{\rm{t}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right) \div \left( {{\rm{si}}{{\rm{n}}^2}{\rm{θ \;}} - {\rm{\;ta}}{{\rm{n}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right)}}{{\left( {{\rm{cose}}{{\rm{c}}^2}{\rm{θ \;}} + {\rm{\;se}}{{\rm{c}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right){{\left( {1{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;co}}{{\rm{t}}^2}{\rm{θ }}} \right)}^2}}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{{\rm{se}}{{\rm{c}}^2}45^\circ \left( {2{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;ta}}{{\rm{n}}^2}45^\circ + {\rm{\;co}}{{\rm{t}}^2}45^\circ } \right) \div \left( {{\rm{si}}{{\rm{n}}^2}45^\circ {\rm{\;}} - {\rm{\;ta}}{{\rm{n}}^2}45^\circ } \right)}}{{\left( {{\rm{cose}}{{\rm{c}}^2}45^\circ {\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;se}}{{\rm{c}}^2}45^\circ } \right){{\left( {1{\rm{\;}} + {\rm{\;co}}{{\rm{t}}^2}45^\circ } \right)}^2}}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{2 \times 4 \div \left( {\frac{1}{2} - 1} \right)}}{{\left( {2 + 2} \right){{\left( {1 + 1} \right)}^2}}}\)
\(\Rightarrow \frac{{2 \times 4 \times \left( { - 2} \right)}}{{4 \times {2^2}}}\)
⇒ -16/16
⇒ -1
∴ The value is -1.
Important Points

Question:
Study the given graph and answer the question that follows.

The number of patients aged 10 or more years but below 40 years is what per cent less than the number of patients aged 50 or more years but below 80 years?
Solution:
Given:
Age of person between 10 to 40 years = 14 + 20 + 24
Age of person between 50 to 80 years = 32 + 26 + 22
Formula used:
Required Percentage = (Age b/w 50 - 80 – Age b/w 10 - 40)/Age b/w 50 - 80 × 100
Calculation:
Age of person between 10 to 40 years = 14 + 20 + 24
⇒ Age b/w 10 - 40 = 58
Age of person between 50 to 80 years = 32 + 26 + 22
⇒ Age b/w 50 - 80 = 80
Required Percentage = (Age b/w 50 - 80 – Age b/w 10 - 40)/Age b/w 50 - 80 × 100
⇒ Required percentage = (80 – 58)/80 × 100
⇒ Required percentage = 22/80 × 100
⇒ Required percentage = 27.5%
∴ The required percentage is 27.5%.

Question: If (x + 20)% of 250 is 25% more than x% of 220, then 10% of (x + 50) is what percent less than 15% of x?
Solution:
Given:
(x + 20)% of 250 = 125% of x% of 220
Concept used:

Calculation:
(x + 20)% of 250 = 125% of x% of 220
⇒ (x + 20)% × 250 = 125% × x% × 220
⇒ (x + 20)/100 × 250 = 125/100 × x/100 × 220
⇒ (x + 20) = 5 × x/100 × 22
⇒ (x + 20) = x/20 × 22
⇒ x + 20 = 11x/10
⇒ 11x/10 – x = 20
⇒ x/10 = 20
⇒ x = 200
10% of (x + 50)
⇒ 10/100 × 250
⇒ 25
15% of x
⇒ 15/100 × 200
⇒ 30
Required percent = (30 – 25)/30 × 100
⇒ Required percent = 5/30 × 100
⇒ Required percent = 50/3
∴ 10% of (x + 50) is \(16\frac{2}{3}\%\)less than 15% of x.

Question: Remi earns a profit of 20% on selling an article at a certain price If she sells the articles for Rs. 8 more, she will gain 30% What is the original cost price of 16 such articles?
Solution:
Given:
Profit = 20%
New profit if sells Rs. 8 more = 30%
Concept used:
Selling price = (100 + Profit)% of C.P.
Calculation:
Let the C.P. of an article be Rs. x.
According to the question,
120% of C.P. + 8 = 130% of C.P.
⇒ 130% of x – 120% of x = 8
⇒ 10% of x = 8
⇒ 10/100 × x = 8
⇒ x = 80
Original C.P. of 16 article = 16x
⇒ Required C.P. = 16 × 80
⇒ Required C.P. = Rs. 1280
∴ The original cost price of 16 such articles is Rs. 1280.

Question: In ΔPQR, O is the in-center and ∠R = 42°. Find the measure of ∠QOP.
Solution:
Given:
In ΔPQR, O is the incentre
∠R = 42°
Concept used:
In ΔPQR,
∠QOP = 90° + ∠R/2
∠QOR = 90° + ∠P/2
∠POR = 90° + ∠Q/2
Calculations:

∠QOP = 90° + 42°/2
⇒ 90° + 21°
⇒ 111°
∴ ∠QOP is 111°.

Question: The sum of the presents age of a father and son is 52 years Four years hence, the son's age will be 1/4 that of the father. What will be the ratio of the age of the son and father, 10 years from now?
Solution:
Given:
Father’s present age + Son’s present age = 52 years
Son’s age after 4 years = 1/4 × Father’s age after 4 years
Concept used:
Using the concept of the linear equation.
Calculation:
Let the present age of the son be x years.
And the present age of the father is (52 – x) years.
According to the question,
Son’s age after 4 years = 1/4 × Father’s age after 4 years
⇒ (x + 4) = 1/4 × (52 – x + 4)
⇒ (x + 4) × 4 = 56 – x
⇒ 4x + 16 = 56 – x
⇒ 5x = 40
⇒ x = 8 years
Son’s present age = 8 years
Father’s present age = 52 – 8
⇒ Father’s present age = 44 years
Required ratio = (Age of son after 10 years)/(Age of father after 10 years)
⇒ Required ratio = (8 + 10)/(44 + 10)
⇒ Required ratio = 18/54
⇒ Required ratio = 1/3
∴ The ratio of the age of the son and father, 10 years from now is 1 ∶ 3.

Question: \(\left(\frac{1}{\cos\theta}-\frac{1}{\sin\theta}\right)+\frac{1}{\text{cosec}\ \theta-\cot\theta}-\frac{1}{\sec\theta+\tan\theta}=?\)
Solution:
Given:
\(\left(\frac{1}{\cos\theta}-\frac{1}{\sin\theta}\right)+\frac{1}{\text{cosec}\ \theta-\cot\theta}-\frac{1}{\sec\theta+\tan\theta}=?\)
Formula used:
Sin2θ + cos2θ = 1
Cosec2θ – cot2θ = 1
sec2θ – tan2θ = 1
Calculation:
\(\left(\frac{1}{\cos\theta}-\frac{1}{\sin\theta}\right)+\frac{1}{\text{cosec}\ \theta-\cot\theta}-\frac{1}{\sec\theta+\tan\theta}=?\)
\(\Rightarrow \left( {{{\sec\theta }} - {{\text{cosec}\ \theta }}} \right) + \frac{1}{{{{\text{cosec}\ \theta }} - {{\cot\ \theta }}}} \times \frac{{{{\text{cosec}\ \theta }} + {{\cot\theta }}}}{{{{\text{cosec}\ \theta }} + {\rm{cot\ \theta }}}} - {\rm{\;}}\frac{1}{{{\rm{sec\ \theta }} + {\rm{tan\ \theta }}}} \times \frac{{{\rm{sec\ \theta }} - {\rm{tan\ \theta }}}}{{{\rm{sec\ \theta }} - {\rm{tan\ \theta }}}} = {\rm{\;}}?\)
\(\Rightarrow \left( {\sec\theta - \;\text{cosec}\ \theta } \right)\; + \;\frac{{cosec\ \theta + cot\ \theta }}{{\text{cose}{c^2}\ \theta - \;co{t^2}\ \theta }}\; - \;\;\frac{{sec\ \theta - tan\ \theta }}{{se{c^2}\ \theta - \;ta{n^2}\ \theta }} = \;?\)
⇒ secθ – cosecθ + cosecθ + cotθ – secθ + tanθ = ?
⇒ cotθ + tanθ = ?
⇒ cosθ/sinθ + sinθ/cosθ = ?
⇒ (cos2θ + sin2θ)/(sinθ × cosθ) = ?
⇒ 1/(sinθ × cosθ) = ?
⇒ ? = secθ × cosecθ
∴ ? is secθ × cosecθ.

Question: A takes 2 hours more than B to cover a distance of 40 km. If A doubles his speed, he takes \(1\frac{1}{2}\) hours more than B to cover 80 km. To cover a distance of 90 km, how much time will B take travelling at his same speed?
Solution:
Calculation:
In the first Case i.e total distance = 40 km
Let the time taken by B = t
So, Time taken by A = (t + 2) hr
We know that Distance = Speed × Time
So, 40 = (t + 2) × SA[Speed of A] -----(i)
In second case i.e total distance = 80 km
So, time taken by B = 2t [Distance ∝ Time, when speed is same]
So, Time taken by A = [2t + (3/2)] hr
Again, 80 = [2t + (3/2)] × 2SA -----(ii)
Multiplying 2 on both side in equation (i), we get
80 = (t + 2) × 2SA -----(iii)
From (i) and (iii), we get
[2t + (3/2)] = (t + 2)
⇒ t = 1/2
Now, time taken by B to cover 40 km is 1/2
Speed of B (SB) = 40 ÷ (1/2) = 80 km/hr
∴ Required time = 90/80 = \(1\frac{1}{8} \ hr\)

Alternate Method
Given :
Distance = 40 km
A takes 2 hrs more than B to cover 40 km
A takes 1.5 hrs more than B to cover 80 km
To find :
Time taken by B to cover 90 km
Formula used :
Distance = speed × time
Solution :
Let the speed of B be x kmph
⇒ Time taken by B to cover 40 km = 40/x
⇒ Time taken by A = (40/x) + 2
So, the speed of A = (20x)/(20 + x) ----(1)
Now,
Distance = 80 km
⇒ Time taken by B to cover 80 km = 80/x ----(2)
⇒ Speed of A when he doubles his speed = (40x)/(20 + x)
⇒ Time taken by A to cover 80 km = (40 + 2x)/(x) ----(3)
A.T.Q.,
From (2) and (3)
(80/x) + (3/2) = (40 + 2x)/x
\(⇒ \frac{{40\; + 2x}}{x} - \frac{{80}}{x} = \frac{3}{2}\;\)
⇒ 2 (40 + 2x - 80) = 3x
⇒ 2 (2x - 40) = 3x
⇒ 4x - 80 = 3x
⇒ 4x - 3x = 80
⇒ x = 80
⇒ Speed of B = 80 kmph
Distance = 90 km
Time taken by B = 90/80
∴ time taken by B to cover 90 km is \(1{1 \over 8}\) hrs.

Question: On selling an article for Rs 123.40, the gain is 20% more than the amount of loss incurred on selling it for Rs.108. If the article is sold for Rs. 120.75, then what is the gain/loss per cent?
Solution:
Given :
When article sold at Rs. 123.40 it gains
When article sold at Rs. 108 it losses
Gain is 20% more than the loss
To find :
Gain or loss when article sold at Rs. 120.75
Formula used :
Loss = cost price - selling price
Gain = selling price - cost price
Gain% = (Gain/cost price) × 100
Solution :
Let the cost price be x
It losses when selling price = Rs. 108
⇒ Loss = (x - 108) ----(1)
It gains when selling price = Rs. 123.40
⇒ Gain = (123.40 - x)
A.T.Q.,
(123.4 - x) = (x - 108) × (120/100)
⇒ 1234 - 10x = 12x - 1296
⇒ 22x = 2530
⇒ x = 115
So, cost price = Rs. 115
Now,
Selling price = 120.75
⇒ Gain = 120.75 - 115
⇒ Gain = 5.75
⇒ Gain% = (5.75/115) × 100
⇒ Gain% = 5%
∴ The gain% when sold at Rs. 120.75 is 5%.

Question: In ΔPQR, ∠Q = 84°, ∠R = 48°, PS ⊥ QR at S and the bisector of ∠P meets QR at T. What is the measure of ∠SPT?
Solution:
Given :
∠Q = 84°
∠R = 48°
∠PSR = 90°
PT bisects ∠QPR
To find :
∠SPT
Concept used :
The Sum of all angle of a triangle is 180°
Calculation :

In ΔPQR
∠QPR + ∠Q + ∠R = 180°
⇒ ∠QPR + 84° + 48° = 180°
⇒ ∠QPR = 180° - 132°
⇒ ∠QPR = 48° ----(1)
⇒ ∠QPT = (∠QPR/2)
⇒ ∠QPT = 48°/2 (from 1)
⇒ ∠ QPT = 24° ----(2)
Now,
In ΔQPT
∠QPT + ∠PQT + ∠PTQ = 180°
⇒ 24° + 84° + ∠PTQ = 180° (from 2)
⇒ ∠PTQ = 180° - 108°
⇒ ∠PTQ = 72° ----(3)
Now,
In ΔPST
∠PST + ∠PTS + ∠SPT = 180°
⇒ 90° + 72° + ∠SPT = 180° (from 3)
⇒ ∠SPT = 180° - 162°
⇒ ∠SPT = 18°
∴ the measure of ∠SPT is 18°
Alternate Method
∠Q + ∠R + ∠P = 180°
∠P/2 = 90° - (∠Q + ∠R)/2 = 90° - (48° + 84°)/2 = 24°
Now
∠PTS = ∠P/2 + ∠R
∠SPT = 180° - ∠PTS - ∠PST
∠SPT = 180° - ∠P/2 - ∠R - 90° = 90° - ∠P/2 - ∠R
∠SPT = 90° - 24° - 48° = 18°

Question: In ΔABC, ∠A = 90° AD is the bisector of ∠A meeting BC at D, and DE ⊥ AC at E. If AB = 10 cm and AC = 15 cm, then the length of DE, in cm, is:
Solution:
Given :
∠A = 90°
AD is the bisector of ∠A
DE ⊥ AC
AB = 10 cm
AC = 15 cm
To find :
The length of DE
Concept used :
Similarity of Triangle
Solution :

As AD is the bisector of ∠CAB
So, ∠EAD = 90°/2
⇒ ∠EAD = 45°
In ΔEAD
⇒ ∠AED + ∠EAD + ∠EDA = 180°
⇒ 90° + 45° + ∠EDA = 180°
⇒ ∠EDA = 180° - 135°
⇒ ∠EAD = 45°
So. EA = ED
Let ED be x
⇒ EC = 15 - x
In ΔCED and ΔCAB
⇒ ∠C = ∠C (common)
⇒ ∠CED = ∠CAB = 90°
So, ΔCED ~ ΔCAB (AA)
⇒ (ED)/(AB) = (CE)/(CA)
⇒ x/10 = (15 - x)/15
⇒ 15x = 10(15 - x)
⇒ 15x = 150 - 10x
⇒ 15x + 10x = 150
⇒ 25x = 150
⇒ x = 150/25
⇒ x = 6
∴ The length of DE is 6 cm.

Question: The base of a pyramid is a square of side 10 cm. If its height is 10 cm, then the area (in cm<sup>2</sup>) of its lateral suface is:
Solution:
Given:
The base of the pyramid is a square
Side of square = 10 cm
Height of pyramid = 10 cm
Concept used:
Lateral surface = (1/2) × Perimeter of the base × Slant height
Calculations:

Slant height = EF
Height = EO = 10 cm
OF = 10/2 = 5 cm
In ΔEOF,
EF2 = OE2 + OF2
⇒ 102 + 52
⇒ EF = √125 = 5√5
Slant height = EF = 5√5 cm
Perimeter of the base = 4 × 10 = 40 cm
Lateral surface = (1/2) × Perimeter of the base × Slant height
⇒ (1/2) × 40 × 5√5
⇒ 100√5 cm
∴ The lateral surface are of the pyramid is 100√5 cm2

Question: The compound interest on a sum of Rs. 5,500 at 15% p.a. for 2 years, when the interest is compounded every 8 months, is:
Solution:
Given :
Principal, P = Rs. 5500
Rate of interest, R = 15%
Time, T = 2 years
Interest is compounded at every 8 months.
To find :
Compound interest
Formula used :
\({\rm{C}}.{\rm{I}}. = {\rm{P\;}}\left[ {{{\left( {1 + \frac{{\rm{R}}}{{100}}} \right)}^T} - 1} \right]\)
Solution :
Time for compounded at every 8 months = 2 × (12/8)
⇒ Time for compounded at every 8 months = 3 units
Rate of interest for compounded at every 8 months = 15 × (8/12)
⇒ Rate of interest for compounded 8 monthly = 10 units
\(⇒ {\rm{C}}.{\rm{I}}. = 5500\left[ {{{\left( {1 + \frac{{10}}{{100}}} \right)}^3} - 1} \right]\)
\(⇒ {\rm{C}}.{\rm{I}}.= 5500\left[ {{{\left( {\frac{{11}}{{10}}} \right)}^3} - 1} \right]\)
\(⇒ {\rm{C}}.{\rm{I}}. = 5500\left[ {\frac{{1331}}{{1000}} - 1} \right]\)
\(⇒ {\rm{C}}.{\rm{I}}. = 5500\left[ {\frac{{\left( {1331 - 1000} \right)}}{{1000}}} \right]\)
\(⇒ {\rm{C}}.{\rm{I}}.= 5500 × \frac{{331}}{{1000}}\)
⇒ C.I. = 55 × (331/10)
⇒ C.I. = 1820.5
∴ the compound interest earned is Rs. 1820.5
NOTE
Since interest is compounded not yearly it is applied at 8 months
and 2-year time is given means 24 months
so 24/8 = 3 times interest will be applied.

Question: The value of \(\left( {2.\bar 4 \times 0.\bar 6 \times 30 \times 0.1\bar 6} \right) \times \left[ {0.2\bar 7 \times \left( {0.8\bar 3 \div 0.1\bar 6} \right)} \right]\) is
Solution:
Given :
\(\left( {2.\bar 4 \times 0.\bar 6 \times 30 \times 0.1\bar 6} \right) \times \left[ {0.2\bar 7 \times \left( {0.8\bar 3 \div 0.1\bar 6} \right)} \right]\)
Concept used :

Convert decimal into fraction
Calculation :
\(\left( {2.\bar 4 \times 0.\bar 6 \times 30 \times 0.1\bar 6} \right) \times \left[ {0.2\bar 7 \times \left( {0.8\bar 3 \div 0.1\bar 6} \right)} \right]\)
\(⇒ \left( {\frac{{22}}{9} \times \frac{2}{3} \times 30 \times \frac{1}{6}} \right) \times \left[ {\frac{5}{{18}} \times \left( {\frac{5}{6} \div \frac{1}{6}} \right)} \right]\)
\(⇒ \left( {\frac{{22}}{9} \times \frac{2}{3} \times 30 \times \frac{1}{6}} \right) \times \left[ {\frac{5}{{18}} \times \left( {\frac{5}{6} \times 6} \right)} \right]\)
\(⇒ \left( {\frac{{22}}{9} \times \frac{2}{3} \times 30 \times \frac{1}{6}} \right) \times \left[ {\frac{{25}}{{18}}} \right]\)
\(⇒ \left( {\frac{{22}}{9} \times 10 \times \frac{1}{3}} \right) \times \frac{{25}}{{18}}\)
\(⇒ \frac{{22}}{9} \times 5 \times \frac{1}{3} \times \frac{{25}}{9}\;\)
⇒ (2750/243)
⇒ 11.31
∴ The value of \(\left( {2.\bar 4 \times 0.\bar 6 \times 30 \times 0.1\bar 6} \right) \times \left[ {0.2\bar 7 \times \left( {0.8\bar 3 \div 0.1\bar 6} \right)} \right]\)​ is 11.31
Note:-
How to solve recurring values takes examples 2.4̅ and 0.83̅
First Example
2.4̅
⇒ x =2.4444.... ----(1)
Multiply by 10 in the above equation
⇒ 10x = 24.4444..... ----(2)
Subtract equation 1 from equation 2
⇒ 9x = 22

Question: A sold a watch to B at a profit of 20%. B sold it to C at 30% profit. C sold it to D at 10% loss. If B's profit is Rs. 80 more than that of A, then D bought it for.
Solution:
Given :
A sold a watch to B at a profit of 20%.
B sold it to C at 30% profit
C sold it to D at 10% loss
B's profit is Rs. 80 more than that of A
To find :
At what price D bought.
Formula used :
Selling price = cost price + profit
Selling price = cost price - loss
Solution :
Let A purchased at Rs. 100
⇒ A sold to B at a 20% profit = 100 × (120/100)
⇒ A sold to B at a 20% profit = 120
⇒ A's profit = 120 - 100
⇒ A's profit = 20 ----(1)
⇒ B sold to C at a 30% profit = 120 × (130/100)
⇒ B sold to C at 30% profit = 156
⇒ B's profit = 156 - 120
⇒ B's profit = 36 ----(2)
⇒ C sold to D at a 10% loss = 156 × (90/100)
⇒ C sold to D at a 10% loss = 140.4
From (1) and (2)
The difference in profit of B and A
⇒ B's profit - A's profit = 36 - 20
⇒ B's profit - A's profit = 16
So. 16x = 80
⇒ x = 5
⇒ D bought it for 140.4 × 5
∴ D bought it for Rs. 702.

Question: The value of \(\left[ {\frac{4}{7}\rm \;of\;2\frac{4}{5} \times 1\frac{2}{3} - \left( {3\frac{1}{2} - 2\frac{1}{6}} \right)} \right] \div \left( {3\frac{1}{5} \div 4\frac{1}{2}\;\rm of\;\;5\frac{1}{3}} \right)\) is:
Solution:
Given :
\(\left[ {\frac{4}{7}\;\rm of\;2\frac{4}{5} × 1\frac{2}{3} - \left( {3\frac{1}{2} - 2\frac{1}{6}} \right)} \right] \div \left( {3\frac{1}{5} \div 4\frac{1}{2}\;\rm of\;5\frac{1}{3}} \right)\)
Concept used :

Calculation :
= \(\left[ {\frac{4}{7}\;\rm of\;\frac{{14}}{5}\; × \frac{5}{3} - \left( {\frac{7}{2} - \frac{{13}}{6}} \right)} \right] \div \left( {\frac{{16}}{5} \div \frac{9}{2}\;\rm of\;\frac{{16}}{3}} \right)\)
= \(\left[ {\;\frac{8}{3} - \left( {\frac{{21 - 13}}{6}} \right)\;} \right] \div \left( {\frac{{16}}{5} × \frac{1}{{24}}} \right)\)
